newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Gunmen kill 21 worshippers at Pakistan mosque.
newsitem.headline: Gunmen kill 21 worshippers at Pakistan mosque.

text.p: Gunmen killed 21 worshippers at a Sunni Moslem mosque in Pakistan on Monday and a militant Shi'ite Moslem leader was shot dead in a nearby town.

Three attackers fired automatic rifles at Al-Khair mosque in the central city of Multan during dawn prayers, killing 21 people and wounding dozens, many of them boys studying at a Koranic school attached to the mosque, ambulance workers said.
The assailants escaped in a car driven by an accomplice.
Troops later patrolled the area in armoured carriers and enforced an undeclared curfew to quell unrest after angry crowds fought police and stoned Shi'ite neighbourhoods, witnesses said.
"The people are understandably very agitated," said police deputy superintendent Mirza Maqbool Beg at the scene.
Shops in the city, in the populous province of Punjab, were shut and many fearful residents stayed at home.
Shahid Ansari, a local councillor in Multan, said his father had been in the mosque, but had escaped unhurt.

"He told me that as soon as the worshippers kneeled in prayer, the gunmen opened up with automatic weapons, firing from three sides," he said. "The shooting went on for five minutes and there was blood and bits of flesh all over the mosque."

Hours later, gunmen on a motorcyle killed Mumtaz-ul-Hassan, local head of the Shi'ite Tehrik-i-Jafria Pakistan (TJP) group, on his way to evening prayers in Bahawalpur, 95 km (60 miles) south of Multan, Shi'ite sources said.
It was the second murder of a militant Shi'ite leader in Bahawalpur in as many days. On Sunday night, gunmen killed Qamar Haider, a local leader of the Sipah-i-Mohammad Pakistan group.
Hardline Sunni and Shi'ite groups have long waged a bloody feud in Pakistan, whose mainly Sunni population of 130 million has a Shi'ite minority of about 15 percent.
In Karachi, a spokesman for the radical Sunni Sipah-i-Sahaba (SSP) group blamed the TJP for the Multan mosque attack.
"It is not my suspicion. I am sure that it was TJP men who killed the innocent worshippers," Tariq Madni, the SSP's information secretary, told Reuters by telephone.
"This is open terrorism. This is the height of cowardice," he said, describing the victims as innocent Sunni Moslems.
"Some of them may have been supporters of the SSP but they were not party members," he added.
He urged Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government to act against the culprits to prevent more sectarian bloodshed.
TJP leaders could not immediately be reached for comment.
Bhutto's government is already reeling from Friday's killing of her estranged younger brother Murtaza, 42, and six of his followers in a clash between his guards and police in Karachi.
